On 5 March 2011 23:14, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> wrote:
>
> synthetic solar panels are much more efficient than photosynthesis. so it seems odd to
> use that as an example of something nature dominates us on. there are so many
> examples where we don't compare at all to natural designs, that you might raise fewer
> red flags by going with an undebatable one.

Some of these arguments that Ken has put forward pivot on where you
draw certain lines and I suspect this may be a source of
misunderstanding and disagreement. E.g. We can make solar cells that
are more efficient than photosynthesis, in fact in the lab we can make
*very* efficient cells, but cells which are not commercially viable.
So on the simple efficiency metric nature loses. And yet globally
photosynthesis is the dominant form of solar energy capture (I'm
actually just guessing here, but I think I'm on pretty safe ground :),
so nature wins on that metric. The reason being that nature wins on
the large scale economics metric - it can make its solar cell
equivalents insanely cheaply from stuff that is just lying around
(dirt, water, etc.), no human labour and no expensive manufacturing
facilities.

I suspect this same line of thinking can be applied to many of the
domains discussed. The naive view of scientific innovation is that
someone figures out how do something and that becomes a game changer -
whereas in reality the economic factors of how do you manufacture
product X or offer service Y are the biggest barriers to success. This
certainly applies to medicine (e.g. cancer treatment) where we now
have very costly drugs and health care systems having to draw the line
somewhere due to money constraints. Just because you can solve some
problem for a specific case in a lab doesn't mean you can solve it
generally. Nature does pretty well on the economics front, mainly
because it widely utilises cheap nanoscale engineering.

Colin
